interactives.title: Pressure Equilibrium
interactives.subtitle: Explore how heat and number of molecules affect pressure equilibrium between two gases.
about: There are gases on both sides of a moveable barrier (piston), which stays in the same place
(more or less) when you run the model because the gas pressure on the piston is in equilibrium.
Add purple gas molecules and watch what happens to the piston. Reset the model. Now add
yellow gas molecules. What happens to the piston?
Try heating or cooling the gas molecules. Explain the change in equilibrium with each
change. Which has a greater effect on equilibrium -- changing the number of gas molecules
or changing the temperature? Why?

interactives.title: The Temperature-Pressure Relationship
interactives.subtitle: Consider how temperature affects the pressure exerted by a gas.
interactives.about: Run the model and change the temperature. What happens to the pressure when the temperature changes?

interactives.title: The Volume-Pressure Relationship
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the volume of a gas affects pressure.
about: Gases can be compressed into smaller volumes. How does compressing a gas affect its pressure?
Run the model, then change the volume of the containers and observe the change in pressure.
The moving wall converts the effect of molecular collisions into pressure and acts as a pressure gauge.
What happens to the pressure when the volume changes?
*Note: Although the atoms in this model are in a flat plane, volume is calculated using 0.1 nm as the depth of the container.*

interactives.subtitle: This is an AgentScript model created by the HAS project

interactives.title: JSmol model
interactives.subtitle: This is an external JSmol model included using Lab iframe model type
about: Open Interactive JSON editor to see three ways of communication with JSmol model:
- one way property binding (*showAxes*),
- direct *.post('jsmolScript', '<script source>')* calls,
- convenience method provided by JSmol embeddable page, e.g. *jsmolScript('<script source>')*
which is equal to *.post('jsmolScript', '<script source>')*.
To check what message types and convenience methods are supported by JSmol model, please see
source of [JSmol embeddable page](http://concord-consortium.github.io/jsmol-models/embeddable.html)
or [JSmol models github repository](https://github.com/concord-consortium/jsmol-models).

interactives.title: JSmol model with two molecules
interactives.subtitle: Demo presenting multiple JSmol molecules and interactions with them
about: Open Interactive JSON editor to see how two molecules are defined and how to commonicate with
them.
You have to define special property **moleculesCount** after # in the JSmol embeddable page URL.
You cannot define this parameter inside standard model properties section.
To communicate with models, you can use exactly the same techniques like for single molecule.
To define scope of JSmol script or property, use special prefixes: **m0:**, **m1:**, **m2:**, etc.
When you do not specify prefix, script or property will be applied to **all** molecules.

interactives.title: Pendulum: rod length and mass
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the factors of rod length and mass affect the period of a pendulum.
about: Adjust the **Rod length**, **Mass of the ball** and **Starting angle** parameters.
Then click the **Start** button to start an experiment run. Watch the **Pendulum Angle**
graph to see how the angle of the pendulum changes as it swings back and forth.
Use the graph to determine the period of the pendulum. Try changing each parameter
and observe how each one affects the period. Can you explain why?
After closing this window click the **?** help icon in the upper left to find out more.

interactives.title: Pendulum 180: rod length and mass
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the factors of starting angles up to 180, rod length and mass affect the period of a pendulum.
about: Adjust the **Rod length**, **Mass of the ball** and **Starting angle** parameters.
Then click the **Start** button to start an experiment run. Watch the **Pendulum Angle**
graph to see how the angle of the pendulum changes as it swings back and forth.
Use the graph to determine the period of the pendulum. Try changing each parameter
and observe how each one affects the period. Can you explain why?
After closing this window click the **?** help icon in the upper left to find out more.

interactives.title: Double Pendulum
interactives.subtitle: Explore a double pendulum.
about: Adjust the **Rod length**, **Mass of the ball** and **Starting angle** parameters.
Then click the **Start** button to start an experiment run. Watch the **Pendulum Angle**
graph to see how the angle of the pendulum changes as it swings back and forth.
Use the graph to determine the period of the pendulum. Try changing each parameter
and observe how each one affects the period. Can you explain why?
After closing this window click the **?** help icon in the upper left to find out more.

interactives.title: Pendulum
interactives.subtitle: Explore some factors that affect the period of a pendulum.
about: Press the play button. Watch the graph to see how the angle of the pendulum changes as it
swings back and forth. Use the graph to determine the period of the pendulum. Adjust the
scale by dragging the numbers on the axes. Change each variable  gravity, rod length,
starting angle and mass  and observe how each one affects the period. Can you explain why?
Try the damping slider. Does damping change the period?

interactives.title: Spring and Mass
interactives.subtitle: Explore some factors that affect the period of a spring.
about: Press the play button. Watch the graph to see how the height of the mass changes as
it moves up and down. Use the graph to determine the period of the mass-spring system.
Adjust the scale by dragging the numbers on the axes. Change each variable  gravity,
spring constant, starting distance and mass  and observe how each one affects the period.
Can you explain why? Is this different from the relationships for a pendulum? Try the
damping slider. Does damping change the period?

interactives.title: Pendulum and Spring
interactives.subtitle: Explore the motion of a pendulum on a spring.
about: Press the play button. Watch the graphs to see the motion of the spring pendulum.
Can you distinguish the pattern of spring motion (up and down) from the pattern
of pendulum motion (back and forth)? How are the two related? Is there a regular
pattern to the motion? Compare the periods of the two graphs. How many different
patterns can you produce by changing the variables  gravity, rod length, mass and
spring constant? Under what conditions does the energy switch between back and forth
and up and down? Does the initial starting angle affect the patterns when all the
other variables are unchanged?

interactives.title: Concentration and Breathing
interactives.subtitle: Exchanging gases across a cell membrane

interactives.title: Diffusion and Concentration
interactives.subtitle: Exchanging molecules across a cell membrane
about: Cell membranes are composed of two layers of phospholipids (a phospholipid bilayer). Some molecules are capable of crossing this membrane directly, without use of specific membrane channels.

Oxygen and carbon dioxide are two molecules that can freely cross the cell membrane. In aerobic cells, oxygen is necessary for cell functioning and carbon dioxide is produced as a waste molecule. Hence, the cell wants oxygen to enter and carbon dioxide to leave. But molecules dont move only in one directionthey diffuse randomly across the membrane.
Set up the model with high oxygen and low carbon dioxide outside the cell and low oxygen and high carbon dioxide inside the cell. In which direction do the oxygen and carbon dioxide molecules move?

interactives.title: Lactase Enzyme Simulation
about: **Lactase Enzyme Action**
Lactase is an enzyme that catalyzes the breakdown of lactose into glucose and galactose. The speed at which lactose is broken down is regulated by the temperature and pH of the environment.
Measure the level of glucose in the lactose/lactase solution in the test tube using a glucose meter. Use the sliders to explore how changing the solution affects glucose production.

interactives.title: Terminal Velocity
interactives.subtitle: Explore parachutes and air resistance.
about: If you've ever felt the wind in your face while riding a bike, then you have felt air resistance.
The faster you go the harder air resistance pushes back. Skydivers rely on this force
to prevent them from continually going faster and faster. Eventually, at some particular speed the
force from air resistance is equal to the force of gravity and the skydiver stops speeding up.
The velocity reached when you stop getting faster is called *terminal velocity* .
Explore factors that affect terminal velocity by using this simulation of a parachute jumper.

interactives.title: Terminal Velocity (not intended for data export)
interactives.subtitle: Explore parachutes and air resistance.
about: If you've ever felt the wind in your face while riding a bike, then you have felt air resistance.
The faster you go the harder air resistance pushes back. Skydivers rely on this force
to prevent them from continually going faster and faster. Eventually, at some particular speed the
force from air resistance is equal to the force of gravity and the skydiver stops speeding up.
The velocity reached when you stop getting faster is called *terminal velocity* .
Explore factors that affect terminal velocity by using this simulation of a parachute jumper.

interactives.title: 3D Exploration of Bound Antibody & Antigen
interactives.subtitle: Discover DNA through antibody/antigen pairings
about: Our immune system works because our bodies manufacture antibodies that are just the right shape to bind with antigens
(molecular fragments of pathogens that enter our bodies).  Explore how the shape of the antibody is complementary to
the shape of the antigen.

which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Mixing Liquids
interactives.subtitle: Explore how liquids mix at the molecular level.
about: How is it possible to mix two liquids together and for them to take up less volume than
when they are separated? Does it always happen that the mixture takes up less space?
How does thinking about liquids as being made of small particles help us understand our
observations? Use this interactive to explore these questions.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Visualizing Electric Fields and Forces
interactives.subtitle: Explore how electric fields relate to forces on charged objects.
about: Control the polarity of the stationary charged object and observe how the charge affects the electric
field around it. Add a second charged object and move it around the stationary object. Explore how the
strength and direction of the forces depends on the charges and distance between the two objects.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Charge surface of amino acid side-chains
interactives.subtitle: Explore three different amino acids.
about: Explore why different amino acids have different properties related to the charge (or lack of charge) on the surface of their side chains.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.* Original Jsmol scripting done for the Science of Atoms and Molecules project DRL-0946582.

interactives.title: Introduction to Amino Acids
interactives.subtitle: Understanding the building blocks of proteins.
about: Click on each scene number in order to zoom into part of a protein and see how amino acids link together to form proteins. You can interact with the molecule at any time
by dragging it around.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.* Original Jsmol scripting done for the Science of Atoms and Molecules project DRL-0946582.

interactives.title: Charge Intensity and Electric Force 2
interactives.subtitle: Manipulate the charge on objects to explore the relationship between charge, electric field, and forces on objects.
about: Control the type of charge on two objects and observe how it affects
(1) the electric fields around the charged objects and
(2) the direction of the forces acting between the two objects.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Charge Intensity and Electric Force
interactives.subtitle: Manipulate the charge on objects to explore the relationship between charge, electric field, and forces on objects.
about: Control the amount of charge on two objects an observe how it affects
(1) the electric fields around the charged objects and
(2) the strength of the forces acting between the two objects.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Atom and Ion Builder (with table)
interactives.subtitle: Making atoms and ions.
about: Explore how changing the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons affects the type of atom. As you build atoms, collect and record
your data in a table. Then draw conclusions about which components affect the type of atom (protons), which components affect the overall
charge of atoms (balance of electrons and protons), and which components affect the isotope type (neutrons).
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Atom and Ion Builder
interactives.subtitle: Making atoms and ions.
about: Explore how changing the numbers of protons, neutrons, and electrons affect the type of atom. As you build atoms,
make observations of the components of different atoms and how they affect the type of atom. Then draw conclusions about
which components affect the type of atom (protons), which components affect the overall charge of atoms (electrons), and
which components affect the size of atoms (neutrons).
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Sticking a Balloon to a Wall
interactives.subtitle: How can a charged balloon stick to a neutral wall?
about: Look at the atoms in a wall and see how the positive and negative parts of the atoms in a neutral wall respond to and interact
with a balloon with different types and amounts of charge.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Boiling point of polar & nonpolar substances
interactives.subtitle: What affects the movement of molecules?
about: Control the temperature and observe the impact on the motion and interactions between particles. Compare
the interactions between nonpolar molecules and between polar molecules to see how polarity affects the
boiling point of substances made from molecules with these properties.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Breaking a Molecular Bond (conceptual version)
interactives.subtitle: Can you break the bond between the two atoms?
about: Try to break different molecules apart by adjusting the initial velocity of
a third atom that will collide with two bonded atoms. Do some bonds require
more energy to break than others? After the collision, compare the changes in energy associated with the different atoms.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Making molecules
interactives.subtitle: Exploring polarization
about: What happens to the distribution of charge in a molecule when atoms within the molecule
are replaced with different ones? Choose different types of atoms to add to an existing
molecule and observe the changes in the electron distribution (charge distribution) of the
molecule when different atoms are substituted at various points on the molecule.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Table: Determining the charge
about: Use this table to collect data so that you can determine the charge (positive or negative)
of the various rods.

interactives.title: Table: Moving a bottle with your hand
about: Use this table to collect data about your experiment with a charged and uncharged bottle.

interactives.title: Table: Interacting with netural objects
about: Use this table to collect data so that you can determine how charged rods interact
with neutral objects.

interactives.title: Table: Comparing the charge of objects after rubbing them together
about: Use this table to collect data so that you can look for patterns in how objects
become charged when rubbed together.

interactives.title: Opposites Attract
interactives.subtitle: Explore how charged objects interact.
about: What causes some things to stick together and other things to push apart? Manipulate the charges on two spheres, making them positive,
negative, or neutral and watch how the spheres interact with each other.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Table: Observations of glowing splint in gasses produced by hydrogen peroxide
about: Use this table to record observations of a glowing splint placed in the gasses above hydrogen
peroxide that was placed in hot and cold water.

interactives.title: Table: Collision experiments
about: Use this table to collect observations of how collisions affect the motions of moving objects.

interactives.title: Collisions and Kinetic Energy
interactives.subtitle: Exploring kinetic energy through collisions.
about: The energy of motion is called *kinetic energy*. The amount of kinetic energy an object has depends
on its mass and speed. Objects that interact with each other can transfer kinetic energy between them.
Use the controls in this interactive to explore how this energy transfer occurs.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Comparing Attractive Forces
interactives.subtitle: Explore different attractive forces between various molecules.
about: Intermolecular attractions are shown by dotted lines between the pairs of molecules.
Choose a pair of molecules from the drop-down menu and "pull" on the star to separate the
molecules. Which pair of molecules is the most difficult to pull apart? Think about what that
means about the polarity of the molecules, and therefore the type of intermolecular forces they exhibit.
This interactive was developed in collaboration with the American Association of Chemistry Teachers.

interactives.title: Comparing Attractive Forces Betweeen Molecules
interactives.subtitle: Differences between polar and nonpolar attractions.
about: Which type of intermolecular attraction is strongest? Explore the different strengths of attractions
between polar and nonpolar molecules. These intermolecular attractions are shown by dotted lines between
the pairs of molecules. Choose a pair of molecules from the drop-down menu and *pull* on the star to separate
them, paying attention to which interactions have the strongest force of attractions.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Comparing Potential Energy of Attractions
interactives.subtitle: Explore the difference in attractive forces between polar and non-polar molecules.
about: Explore the change in potential energy when molecules are separated from each other.
First, choose a pair of molecules or atoms from the drop-down menu and "pull" on the green star to separate them.
Then, compare observations of the potential energy of each molecule or scenario tested.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Comparing Potential Energy of Bond
interactives.subtitle: Explore the difference in attractive forces between polar and non-polar molecules.
about: Explore the change in potential energy when molecules are separated from each other or broken apart.
First, choose a pair of molecules or atoms from the drop-down menu and "pull" on the green star to separate them.
Then, compare observations of the potential energy of each molecule or scenario tested.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Crookes Tube
interactives.subtitle: Simulating J.J. Thomson's discovery of the electron.
about: Participate in a simulation where two electrodes are connected to a high voltage source and see them
produce cathode rays. J.J. Thomson used a similar experimental set up to discover the first subatomic
particle. Based on your observations of the cathode rays, what you can determine about this stream of particles?
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Table: Copper(II) Chloride and Aluminum Experiment
about: Use this table to collect data for this hands-on experiment.

interactives.title: Deformed Electron Cloud
interactives.subtitle: Explore the effect of charges on electron distribution.
about: Explore the effect of charges on the electron distribution of the atom by using slider bars
to alter the charges outside the atom. Then analyze different combinations of outside charges
and observe their effect to draw conclusions about how charges affect the overall shape of atoms.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Table: Determining the charge on rubbed objects
about: Use this table to indicate the charge objects that have been rubbed together have.

interactives.title: Table: Recording diffusion speed of food coloring
about: Use this table to collect data about your experiment with food coloring in water of various temperatures.

interactives.title: Making and Breaking Bonds: The Effect of Temperature
interactives.subtitle: Explore how temperature affects chemical reactions.
about: A chemical reaction can occur in three different ways:
- A chemical bond is formed.
- A chemical bond is broken.
- One or more electrons are transferred between atoms or molecules.
Explore reactions in which chemical bonds are formed and broken. Experiment with  heating and cooling the atoms to
see how temperature affects the balance between bond formation and breaking.
*This simulation was adapted by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Dissolving Experimental
interactives.subtitle: Explore how molecules of different polarity interact when mixed.
about: Select the polarity of two different molecules and simulate what happens when these two molecules of different (or the same)
polarities are mixed. Speed up the simulation to reach an outcome faster, or keep it slow to observe the interactions between atoms.
Then draw conclusions about how polarity impacts how different substances dissolve.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Dissolving
interactives.subtitle: Impact on potential energy when a substance dissolves in water.
about: Add water to a substance and observe the impact on potential energy as the substance dissolves.
Observe the interactions between molecules as the substance dissolves over time and watch what happens
to the potential energy of the system as dissolving occurs.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Predicting self-assembly
interactives.subtitle: Move molecules around to suggest patterns they might form.
about: Select an oil or water environment for molecules and move the soap molecules around
to predict how they will distribute themselves in water or oil.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Diffusion of a Drop (with temperature)
interactives.subtitle: The effect of temperature on diffusion.
about: Click in the model to add dye to a liquid and watch how the dye molecules move through the water.
You  can also trace individual molecules to see how they move through the liquid. During the simulation,
vary the temperature to observe how it affects the diffusion of the dye in water.
*This simulation was adapted by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Electric Potential Energy and Type of Charge
interactives.subtitle: Compare potential energy of oppositely or similarly charged particles.
about: Select the charge of two particles and compare the potential energy of the electric field they generate.
Move the particles closer and farther apart and try different types of charge. Then observe the changes in
potential energy, electric field, and forces generated.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Electric Potential Energy and Charge Intensity
interactives.subtitle: Compare potential energy of particles with varying amounts of charge.
about: Select the amount and type of charge on two particles and explore how the electric field changes,
along with the energy stored in that field. Move the particles closer and farther apart. Observe the changes
in potential energy, electric field, and forces generated.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Conversion of Electric Potential Energy
interactives.subtitle: Explore the conversion of electric potential energy to thermal energy.
about: Select the amount of charge on two particles and compare the potential energy of the electric field they generate.
Then move the particles closer and farther apart. Next, run the model and observe how potential energy is converted into thermal energy.
Changes in forces and fields are also visible to help draw conclusions.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Table: Testing gases electrolysis experiment
about: Use this table to record observations of both a flaming and glowing splint with gases from an electrolysis experiment.

interactives.title: Understanding Probability Maps
interactives.subtitle: Using a color to estimate the next dart throw.
about: As in most dart games, the best shot is a bulls-eye (right in the center). However, it can be hard to get the dart to land there.
Because everyone aims for the center any random dart throw is more likely to be near the center and less likely to be far away.
Use the controls to throw lots of darts and observe the pattern they make. This is similar to how we understand the position of
electrons around an atom's nucleusmore likely in some places and less likely in others.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Exploring Electron Properties
interactives.subtitle: Compare cathode ray particles and charged atoms.
about: J.J. Thomson discovered electrons by studying cathode rays, which were actually streams of electrons.
Compare the behavior of charged atoms and cathode ray particles (electrons) by sending electrons or different
atoms through charged plates. Watch what happens and consider why Thomson thought cathode ray particles could
not be some type of charged atom.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Elements and Polarity
interactives.subtitle: How polarity affects molecular shape and charge.
about: Select from different polar molecules such as water, propanol, mineral oil, and phospholipids.
View these molecules and their shape in different ways to determine how different atom types lead
to areas of different charge on the overall molecular surface.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Exploring Hydrophobic Core
interactives.subtitle: Exploring polar and nonpolar regions on different proteins.
about: Select different proteins and choose which parts of the protein molecule to highlight. Click and drag the molecule to rotate it.
Observe where the polar and nonpolar parts of the protein end up and how they influence the overall structure of the larger protein molecule.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Exploring Protein 3D Structure
interactives.subtitle: Build proteins from amino acid components.
about: View the components of a protein (elements, amino acids) in different colors and zoom into several amino acids
to understand how they link together to make a larger structure.
Using the mouse to drag the protein around, viewing it from different angles, and try "building"
the proteins to see how the large molecule folds up to form a particular shape.
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Table: Explosion Observations
about: Use this table to record observations of the various gases exploding.

interactives.title: Factors Affecting London Dispersion Attractions 2
interactives.subtitle: Explore how differences in molecular size and shape affect the strength of London dispersion attractions.
about: Some non-polar molecules have stronger attractions than others. Choose a pair of
molecules from the drop-down menu and "pull" on the star to separate the molecules.
Why do size and shape affect the strength of attraction between two non-polar molecules?
How does temperature affect the ability of the moleucles to stay stuck together?
*This simulation was developed by [the Interactions project](https://concord.org/projects/interactions "the Interactions Project")
with funding from the National Science Foundation (DRL-1232388) in partnership with
[the CREATE for STEM Institute](http://create4stem.msu.edu/ "the CREATE for STEM Institute") at Michigan State University. To learn more,
[visit the Interactions curriculum collection](https://learn.concord.org/interactions "visit the Interactions curriculum collection") in
which this simulation is embedded.*

interactives.title: Direction of Force on Charged Objects
interactives.subtitle: Explore the direction of an electric force between charged objects.
about: Drag a positively charged object around a stationary object that can be either positive or negative.
Observe the direction and angle of the force on the movable object due to the two charges. Use
the "trace" function to map out a "field" around the central charged object.

Concentration and Reaction Rate
interactives.subtitle: How does concentration affect reaction rate?
about: In this model, two atoms can form a bond to make a molecule.
Experiment with changing the concentration of the atoms in order to see
how this affects the reaction rate (the speed at which the reaction occurs).
Follow these steps:
1. Add some atoms. (You can add atoms by pressing the buttons multiple times).
2. Run the model.
3. Reset the model and try a different concentration.
Gauge the reaction rate by using the graph to see when the reaction reaches 80% completion.

interactives.title: Container Size Challenge
interactives.subtitle: See how fast you can get the reaction below to reach and sustain 80% completion or better
about: This is a challenge model: Using your knowledge of reaction rates, see how fast you can get the reaction below to reach and sustain 80% completion or better.
WHAT TO DO:
START by adding atoms, running the model and watching the temperature.
RESET the container and then change the size of the container by writing a new dimension, e.g. 100, 250, in the 'change container size' space in the the 'change container size' button below.
(Note: You can ONLY resize the container when it is empty. To empty the container use the 'reset' button.)
You can only add 10 atoms to the container.
You can change the temperature by using the slider.

interactives.title: Limiting Reactions

about: WHAT TO DO:
Compare the difference between a combustion reaction that has the exact ratio of reactants with a
reaction that has a limiting reactant. See if you can tell which reactant is considered the
'limiting reactant' in the 2nd model.

interactives.title: Dynamic Equilibrium
interactives.subtitle: Exchanging gases across a cell membrane
about: Cell membranes are composed of two layers of phospholipids (a phospholipid bilayer). Some molecules are capable of crossing this membrane directly, without use of specific membrane channels.

Oxygen and carbon dioxide are two molecules that can freely cross the cell membrane. In aerobic cells, oxygen is necessary for cell functioning and carbon dioxide is produced as a waste molecule. Hence, the cell wants oxygen to enter and carbon dioxide to leave. But molecules dont move only in one directionthey diffuse randomly across the membrane.
Set up the model with high oxygen and low carbon dioxide outside the cell and low oxygen and high carbon dioxide inside the cell. In which direction do the oxygen and carbon dioxide molecules move?

interactives.title: Elastic Collision 1: Two atoms
about: This model shows the collision of two identical atoms.
The redness indicates the kinetic energy of each atom and the arrows indicate the direction and magnitude
of the force between the atoms. If students carefully observe this model they will see that the forces
between the atoms are attractive at moderate distances and repulsive when the atoms get too close together.

interactives.title: Elastic Collision 2: Two atoms with energy graph
about: This model shows the collision of two identical atoms.
It ALSO graphs the kinetic (red), potential (blue) and total (green) energies of each atom.
The redness indicates the kinetic energy of each atom and the arrows indicate the direction
and magnitude of the force between the atoms. Careful observation of the graph will reveal
that energy is conserved and that there is an unexpected drop in the kinetic energy when
the atoms collide as there is no speed, a factor in kinetic energy, at the point of collision.

interactives.title: Elastic Collision 3: Newton's Cradle with paired atoms transmitting energy
about: This is a curiosity; it shows that one can make a Newton's Cradle from atoms.
It does illustrate how energy the energy of two atoms can be transmitted by
collisions down a line of atoms. The reason it is a curiosity is that you never
get atoms so perfectly aligned in the real world.

interactives.title: Elastic Collision 4: Newton's Cradle with single atom transmitting energy
about: This is a curiosity; it shows that one can make a Newton's Cradle from atoms.
It does illustrate how energy the energy of an atom can be transmitted by
collisions down a line of atoms.

interactives.title: The distance between charges matters
interactives.subtitle: Can you manipulate the position of charged particles to steer another object to a target?
about: Use the *Shoot an electron* button to shoot an electron particle across the game board.
Adjust the position of the positively charged object to steer the moving particle to either target.

interactives.title: A Charge Game
interactives.subtitle: Guide a charged object through a maze.
interactives.about: Control the charge of the gray ball by using the -, 0, and + buttons below the game. Use the attractive and repulsive forces between charged objects to navigate through the maze. Can you get it to the target before time runs out?

interactives.title: Convection 4A: Natural convection
interactives.subtitle: Which mechanism transfers heat more quickly, conduction or convection?
about: This model has two parts with a warm surface at the bottom. The right-hand side is a solid material
that happens to have the same conductivity as air. The left-hand side is just air. Warmer air heated
by the hot surface has a buoyant force upward.
**Your task is to compare the rates of the heat flow from the bottom to the top in the two parts.**
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  When the model stops, write the temperatures measured by the thermometers and the temperature at
the bottom heater.
Reset the model. Set the bottom temperature to be **Low** and **High** and repeat steps 1-2, respectively.

interactives.title: Convection 4B: Slow down convection
interactives.subtitle: How can convection be reduced?
about: This model has two compartments with a warm surface at the bottom. In the middle of the
right-hand compartment there is a barrier.
**Your task is to compare the rates of the convective heat transfer from the bottom to the top in the two compartments.**
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  When the model stops, write the temperatures measured by the thermometers and the temperature at the bottom heater.
3.  Try changing the location of the barrier or adding more barriers. Click on the barrier to change size, move, or copy it.
4.  Try to connect what you observe in this model to the attic in a house.

interactives.title: Convection 4C: Forced convection
interactives.subtitle: How does blowing air cool down an object?
about: There are two warm objects in this model, separated by a thin, long insulator in the middle.
In the upper part, there is a fan blowing from left to right. In the lower part, there is no fan blowing.
1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two thermometers.
2.  After the model has run for about 25 model minutes (the time for the model, not real time),
note the temperatures measured by the thermometers.
Set the wind speed to be **Low** and **High** and repeat steps 1-2, respectively.

interactives.title: Convection 4D: The stack effect
interactives.subtitle: Where does the house lose energy?
about: The two rooms each have a heater at the bottom and **leaks** near the top.
1.  Run the model and look for leaking energy.
2.  Click on the wall and roof elements to change the sizes and locations of the leaks.
3.  Note the convection pattern in each situation.

interactives.title: Convection 4E: Blowing wind
interactives.subtitle: Why should you close the windows in a stormy winter day?
about: This model investigates the effect of wind blowing towards a building. The air currents
are indicated by arrows and can be shown by streamlines.
1.  Run the model and note the convection and heating patterns both inside and outside the house,
heated by a heating board on the floor.
2.  Change the wind condition and open or close the windows to examine how heat flow will change.

interactives.title: Pressure Equilibrium
interactives.subtitle: Explore how heat and number of molecules affect pressure equilibrium between two gases.
about: There are gases on both sides of a moveable barrier (piston), which stays in the same place
(more or less) when you run the model because the gas pressure on the piston is in equilibrium.
Add purple gas molecules and watch what happens to the piston. Reset the model. Now add
yellow gas molecules. What happens to the piston?
Try heating or cooling the gas molecules. Explain the change in equilibrium with each
change. Which has a greater effect on equilibrium -- changing the number of gas molecules
or changing the temperature? Why?

interactives.title: Intermolecular Attractions and States of Matter
interactives.subtitle: Explore how states of matter are related to the strength of intermolecular attractions.
about: There are three states of mattersolid, liquid and gas. Run the model and change the
strength of attractions between the molecules. How does changing the force of attraction
between molecules affect the state of that material?

interactives.title: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat
interactives.subtitle: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat in a Melting Experiment
about: Specific heat capacity is the measure of the heat energy required
to raise the temperature of a given quantity of a substance by one
kelvin. Latent heat of melting describes the amount of heat
required to melt a solid. When a solid is undergoing melting, the
temperature basically remains constant until the entire solid is
molten. The simulation demonstrates the specific heat and
the latent heat.
The physical origin of latent heat is that when a system is in a
phase transition, its structure will change. Changing structure
usually results in changes of potential energy, because potential
energy depends primarily on structure. In the simulation,
the energy added to the system is absorbed by the atoms and used
to break the interatomic interactions (so that they can leave the
condensed state). During the phase transition the kinetic energy
doesn't increase, as the
potential energy increases in the expense of the input energy.
During this period, the interatomic interactions diminish and the
structure breaks up, resulting in a phase transition.
One thing you would notice is that the temperature-energy curve on
the right has fluctuations. This is because we have much fewer
atoms (169) in the simulation than there would be in a real
physical model.

interactives.title: Specific Heat and Latent Heat in Condensation
interactives.subtitle: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat in a Condensation Experiment
about: Specific heat capacity is the measure of the heat energy required
to raise the temperature of a given quantity of a substance by one
kelvin. Latent heat of melting describes the amount of heat
required to melt a solid. When a solid is undergoing melting, the
temperature basically remains constant until the entire solid is
molten. The simulation demonstrates the specific heat and
the latent heat.
The physical origin of latent heat is that when a system is in a
phase transition, its structure will change. Changing structure
usually results in changes of potential energy, because potential
energy depends primarily on structure. In the simulation,
the energy added to the system is absorbed by the atoms and used

interactives.title: Phase Changes Caused by Energy Input
interactives.subtitle: Explore how energy input causes matter to change states.
about: Matter exists as solids, liquids and gases, and can change state between these.
The model shows a liquid material on the left (small atoms). The amount of heat
energy is shown by kinetic energy (KE) shading, with deeper shades of red
representing more energetic atoms. On the right side of the barrier is a solid
material (large atoms).
Run the model. How much energy is able to penetrate the barrier? Remove the barrier.
How quickly do the more energetic atoms melt the solid?

interactives.title: Electron Geometry
interactives.subtitle: Explore examples of different molecular shapes
about: Molecules assume different shapes due to patterns of shared and unshared electrons.
In these examples all electrons affecting the shape of the molecules are shared
in the covalent bonds holding the atoms together to form the molecules.

interactives.title: Energy Levels of a Hydrogen Atom
interactives.subtitle: Explore the orbital shapes of hydrogen's electron.
about: The likely location of an electron around the nucleus of an atom
is called an orbital. The shape of an orbital depends on the energy
state of the electron.
A neutral hydrogen atom has one electron. Click in the boxes to set the
energy of that electron and see the orbital shape describing where you are
likely to find that electron around the nucleus.

interactives.title: DNA: The Double Helix
interactives.subtitle: Explore the structure of DNA.
about: Use the controls to explore this fragment of a much longer DNA strand.
Can you find the four different base pairs that DNA is constructed from?

interactives.title: Aquapores
interactives.subtitle: Explore an interactive 3D model of an aquapore.
about: The passage of water into and out of cells is crucial to their function.
However, water cannot directly pass through these membranes. Instead, water
moves through channels made by proteins that bridge the inside and outside
of a cell. Use this interactive to explore the structure of an aquapore channel, which
allows only water to pass into and out of a cell.

interactives.title: Unshared Electrons and the "Bent" Shape
interactives.subtitle: Why is water not linear?
about: Use the 3D model to see how unshared electrons repel
those that are shared in the bonds between hydrogen
and oxygen, causing the molecule to have a "bent" shape.

interactives.title: Land Management 1
interactives.subtitle: Effect of Slope
about: Explore the effect of slope on erosion.
This model is divided into two zones that allow you to compare different slopes.
Change the landscape by choosing a terrain from the pulldown menu.
You can choose from the preset options or set your own slopes.
Watch the graphs to see how soil moves between the zones.
The **Erosion Rate** graph shows the amount of soil in each zone over time.
The **Amount of Topsoil** graph shows the amount of topsoil in each zone over time.

interactives.title: Land Management 2
interactives.subtitle: Effect of Vegetation
about: Explore the effect of slope and plants on erosion.
This model is divided into two zones that allow you to compare different slopes and management plans.
1) Change the landscape by choosing a terrain from the pulldown menu.
You can choose from the preset values or set your own slopes.
2) Choose a management plan for each zone from the pulldown menus. Try planting grass in only one zone.
Watch the graphs to see how soil moves between the zones.
The **Erosion Rate** graph shows the amount of soil in each zone over time.
The **Amount of Topsoil** graph shows the amount of topsoil in each zone over time.

interactives.title: Land Management 3
interactives.subtitle: Effect of Climate on Plant Growth and Erosion
about: Explore the effect of slope, plants, and climatic factors on erosion.
This model is divided into two zones that allow you to compare different slopes and management plans.
1) Change the landscape by choosing a terrain from the pulldown menu.
You can choose from the preset values or set your own slopes.
2) Choose a management plan for each zone from the pulldown menus.
3) Change the climate with the climate controls. You can choose from preset values or set your own monthly precipitation rate.
Watch the graphs to see how soil moves between the zones.
The **Erosion Rate** graph shows the amount of soil in each zone over time.
The **Amount of Topsoil** graph shows the amount of topsoil in each zone over time.

interactives.title: Land Management 5
interactives.subtitle: Conservative Tillage vs. Intensive Tillage
about: In this model, you can explore the effect of slope, plants, climatic factors, and tillage strategy
(preparation of soil for planting) on erosion.
In conservative tillage, the soil is minimally disrupted, while in intensive tillage, the soil is completely tilled.
This model is divided into two zones that allow you to compare different management plans.
1) Change the landscape by choosing a terrain from the pulldown menu.
You can choose from the preset values or set your own slopes.
2) Choose a management plan for each zone from the pulldown menus.
Plant wheat in both zones, but vary the tilling strategy.
3) Change the climate with the climate controls. You can choose from preset values or set your own monthly precipitation rate.
Watch the graphs to see how soil moves between the zones.
The **Erosion Rate** graph shows the amount of soil in each zone over time.
The **Amount of Topsoil** graph shows the amount of topsoil in each zone over time.
The **Soil Quality Key** in the model allows you to monitor how the quality of the soil is affected
by the management plan.

interactives.title: Land Management (master)
interactives.subtitle: Master Model
about: Explore the effect of slope, plants, climatic factors, and tillage strategy
(preparation of soil for planting) on erosion.
In conservative tillage, the soil is minimally disrupted, while in intensive tillage, the soil is completely tilled.
This model is divided into two zones that allow you to compare different management plans.
1) Change the landscape by choosing a terrain from the pulldown menu.
You can choose from the preset values or set your own slopes.
2) Choose a management plan for each zone from the pulldown menus.
Try varying the type of planting and the type of tillage.
3) Change the climate with the climate controls. You can choose from preset values or set your own monthly precipitation rate.
Watch the graphs to see how soil moves between the zones.
The **Erosion Rate** graph shows the amount of soil in each zone over time.
The **Amount of Topsoil** graph shows the amount of topsoil in each zone over time.
The **Soil Quality Key** in the model allows you to monitor how the quality of the soil is affected
by the management plan.

interactives.title: Replacing Bitmap Images with SVG
interactives.subtitle: Experiments replacing bitmap images with SVG documents to preserve quality when scaled up.
about: This Interactive displays an image with a suggestion for how to start using the Interactive.
Current possible images including the SVG replacements for the png image:
1. [instructionBox.png](../../models-converted/lab-version/1/md2d/layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox.png)
This is a 253x58 pixel png image. Will appear pixelated when scaled to larger sizes.
2. [instructionBox.svg](../../models-converted/lab-version/1/md2d/layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox.svg)
Created with Adobe Illustrator this SVG image uses an embedded base64 image for the drop-shadow effect.
Additionally explicit paths are used to draw the text instead of using SVG text objects, this makes the text
rendering independent of whether a specific font is installed on the users computer.
3. [instructionBox2.svg](../../models-converted/lab-version/1/md2d//layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox2.svg)
Created using the open-source Inkscape application this SVG image uses SVG text elements and does not have a drop shadow.
4. [instructionBox3.svg](../../models-converted/lab-version/1/md2d//layout-tests/svg-images/instructionBox3.svg)
Created by hand, this SVG image uses SVG text elements and the SVG feGaussianBlur filter to create the drop-shadow effect.

about: Set the temperature of the substances on either side of the barrier and then allow them to mix.
Notice what happens to the kinetic energy of the molecules and the temperatures of
each substance.

interactives.subtitle: Detecting a Planet by Monitoring Starlight
about: Discover how a planet can dim a star's apparent light intensity (brightness).
Press the **Play** button to start the model.
Move the planet around the model space. Look at the light intensity graph
to discover how light intensity changes as the planet moves
past the star.
Try changing the diameter of the planet. Which planets are more likely to be detected?

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 1
interactives.subtitle: Gravity and Orbits
about: Explore the gravitational effect an orbiting planet has on a star's motion.
Change the planet type to compare the effects of a rocky planet and a gaseous planet on star motion.
Change the diameter of the planet to change the mass, and explore the effect of planet mass on star motion.

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 10
interactives.subtitle: Star Types and Habitable Zones
about: Explore the habitable zone ranges of different star types.
There are five types of stars, classified by their color and temperature.
The blue ring represents the zone around the star where liquid water is possible.
This zone of habitability is different for different types of stars.
The model shows a planet orbiting at 1 au (astronomical unit), about the distance between Earth and our Sun,
for a sense of scale.
How does a star's temperature affect the location of the habitable zone?

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 11
interactives.subtitle: Determining Habitability of a Planet
about: Explore some characteristics of planets and their stars that make habitability possible.
Set up a solar system.
For your star: choose a star type from the preset stars menu.
For your planet: choose from the preset planets or add a customized planet.
To make your own planet, highlight the planet in the model. It will turn red when highlighted.
Move the planet to the distance you want it to orbit the star.
Set the planet type and diameter.
Change the velocity of the planet by highlighting and dragging the vector arrow.
You can try to make an elliptical (oval) orbit, or you can click the **Make circular orbit** button.
The velocity will be changed so that the planet orbits the star in a circle.)
If your planet goes outside the model, reload the model to try again.
When you have finished setting up your solar system, analyze its habitability.
If a characteristic is favorable to life, there will be a . If the characteristic is unfavorable, there will be an X.
Try many different combinations to see if you can answer these questions:
Which star types are conducive to life? What planet type is necessary for life as we know it?
What is the best orbit for supporting life?

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 12
interactives.subtitle: Habitability Challenge
about: Many different factors affect a planet's suitability for life, including:
star type, planet type, planet size, and the planet's orbital distance from its star.
Observe the orbits and star types of Planets A, B, C, and D to predict
which planet would be most habitable.

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 2
interactives.subtitle: Seeing Star Motion With a Telescope: The Effect of Tilt
about: Explore which planetary angles of orbit can be detected by scientists on Earth.
In this model, the telescope is at a right angle (90) to the screen.
(Imagine that you are looking through a telescope focused on the screen to see the star's motion
toward and away from you.).
Not all star motion will be detected by this telescope.
Change the tilt of the orbit by dragging the gridded plane of the model. The current tilt angle is reported in
the lower left of the model.
Which orbital angles can the telescope detect?
(Note that you may need to **Zoom** in on the graph after changing the planet's orbital angle (tilt). You can also clear
current graph data to focus on the newer data only.)

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 3
interactives.subtitle: Effect of Planetary Mass on Star Velocity
about: Explore the effect of a planet's mass on its star's velocity.
Change the orbital angle (tilt) so that you can see the star's movement in the velocity graph.
(Note that you may need to **Zoom** in on the graph after changing the planet's orbital angle (tilt). You can also clear
current graph data to focus on the newer data only.)
Change the planet type to explore the effect of rocky and gaseous planets on planet mass and star motion.
Change the diameter (and therefore, planet mass) of the planet to see the effect of larger and smaller planets
on a star's motion.
Is it possible to have a massive planet that has very little effect on star motion?

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 4
interactives.subtitle: Star Velocity Data With 'Noise'
about: Explore the effect of 'noise' on data interpretation.
In the real world, there is always some 'noise' in the data collected by telescopes.
In this model, you can control the 'precision of the telescope' to discover which types of planets are
most likely to be discovered using real-world telescopes.
Set up the model with a tilt angle and planet that is detectable on the velocity graph.
Then add 'noise' to the data by decreasing the telescope precision.
Is it possible to detect a really small planet when there is a lot of noise in the data?

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 6
interactives.subtitle: Finding a Planet Through Velocity and Light Intensity Methods
about: Explore how combining data from the velocity of a star and the light intensity of a star can be used to find planets.
Adjust the orbital angle (tilt) of the model so that you can see star movement in the velocity graph.
(Note that you may need to **Zoom** in on the graph after changing the planet's orbital angle (tilt). You can also clear
current graph data to focus on the newer data only.)
As the planet passes in front of the star, watch what happens to the light intensity on the light intensity graph.
Change the diameter of the planet and/or test out some of the preset planets.
What type of planet has the largest dimming effect on the star?
Why is it possible to sometimes detect planets on the velocity graph and not on the light intensity graph?

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 7
interactives.subtitle: Star Velocity and Light Intensity Data With 'Noise'
about: Explore the effect of 'noise' on data interpretation.
In the real world, there is always some 'noise' in the data collected by telescopes.
In this model, you can control the 'precision of the telescope' to discover which types of planets are
most likely to be discovered using real-world telescopes.
Set up the model with a tilt angle and planet that is detectable on the velocity and light intensity graphs.
(Note that you may need to **Zoom** in on the graph after changing the planet's orbital angle (tilt). You can also clear
current graph data to focus on the newer data only.)
Then add 'noise' to the data by decreasing the telescope precision.
Is it possible to detect a really small planet when there is a lot of noise in the data?
With which method  velocity or light intensity  are scientists more likely to discover a planet with real-world telescopes?

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 8
interactives.subtitle: Using Star Data to Detect Planets
about: In this model, you get to search for planets just as scientists would. The only information you
have are the graphs of star velocity and light intensity.
Use the graphs of star velocity and light intensity to determine if the star has an orbiting planet.
There are five different stars in this model. You may reload the model to try a different star.

interactives.title: Planet Hunting 9

about: Set up a solar system and challenge your friends to discover planets.

Set the planet type and planet diameter.
Change the velocity of the planet by highlighting and dragging the planet's vector arrow.
(If you want the orbit of your planet to be circular, click the **Make circular orbit** button.
The velocity will be changed so that the planet orbits the star in a circle.)
You can use the velocity arrow to try to make an elliptical (oval) orbit. If your planet goes outside the model,
reload the model to try again.
Set the telescope precision. Set the orbital angle (tilt) of the planet.
Then cover the model and controls, and challenge your friends to find a planet in the data on the velocity and
light intensity graphs.

interactives.title: Planet Hunting (master)

about: Explore how combining data from the velocity of a star and the light intensity of a star can be used to find planets.
Adjust the orbital angle (tilt) of the model so that you can see star movement in the velocity graph.
(Note that you may need to **Zoom** in on the graph after changing the planet's orbital angle (tilt). You can also clear
current graph data to focus on the newer data only.)
As the planet passes in front of the star, watch what happens to the light intensity on the light intensity graph.
Change the diameter of the planet and/or test out some of the preset planets.
What type of planet has the largest dimming effect on the star?
Why is it possible to sometimes detect planets on the velocity graph and not on the light intensity graph?
In the real world, there is always some 'noise' in the data collected by telescopes.
In this model, you can control the 'precision of the telescope' to discover which types of planets are
most likely to be discovered using real-world telescopes.
Set up the model with a tilt angle and planet that is detectable.

Is it possible to detect a really small planet when there is a lot of noise in the data?
