Explore the habitable zone ranges of different star types.
There are five types of stars, classified by their color and temperature.
The blue ring represents the zone around the star where liquid water is possible.
This zone of habitability is different for different types of stars.
Press the **Analyze** button to analyze the likely habitability of your planet.

interactives.title: Wave Generator
interactives.subtitle: Using the Doppler Effect to Detect Star Motion
about: Explore how scientists use changes in a star's light waves to detect a star's movement.
Press the **Play** button to start the model.
Use the slider to move the star closer to and farther from the telescope.
Watch what happens to the color of the light coming from the star.
Why does it change?
Look at the graph of the star's velocity.
Can you tell from the graph alone when the star is moving toward the telescope?

interactives.title: DNA to Protein
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the code embedded in DNA is translated into a protein.
about: Click **Transcribe** to zoom into the cell nucleus and see the chromosome unravel to expose the strands of DNA. The DNA separates and an mRNA strand is created by matching complementary nucleotides.

Click **Translate** to watch the mRNA leave the nucleus for the cytoplasm and attach to a ribosome. tRNA molecules bring in amino acids and the amino acids are added in the correct order by matching complementary nucleotides.
After translation, inspect the protein to see how the amino acid sequence folded.

interactives.title: Modeling Transcription
interactives.subtitle: Explore how an mRNA copy is made of DNA.
about: One strand of the DNA is used as a template to create an mRNA copy. This process is called transcription. An mRNA copy needs to be made because DNA cannot leave the nucleus.
Protein complexes separate the DNA helix to allow complementary mRNA nucleotides to bind to the DNA sequence. The pairing of nucleotides is very specific.
Use the **A**, **U**, **G** and **C** buttons to place the correct mRNA nucleotide with each DNA nucleotide.

interactives.title: Modeling Translation
interactives.subtitle: Explore how a protein is made from an mRNA sequence.
about: Translation, or making a protein from an mRNA sequence, occurs on ribosomes. The amino acids are brought to the ribosome by transfer RNAs (tRNAs).
The tRNA pairs up with the mRNA by matching up complementary nucleotides. This ensures that the correct amino acid is added to the protein.
Can you identify what the tRNA codon will be for each triplet of mRNA nucleotides?

interactives.title: Mutations
interactives.subtitle: Explore how changing the DNA sequence can change the amino acid sequence of a protein.
about: Mutations are mistakes in the DNA sequence. Use the **Edit DNA** button to change the entire sequence or click on an individual nucleotide to make an insertion, deletion or substitution mutation. How does changing the DNA sequence change the resulting protein?
You can quickly jump between the DNA sequence and final protein by using the **Show DNA** and **Show protein** buttons.
Are some types of mutations more damaging than others?

interactives.title: What is a Chemical Reaction?
about: A chemical reaction can occur in three different ways:
- A chemical bond is formed.
- A chemical bond is broken.
- One or more electrons are transferred between atoms or molecules.
Explore reactions in which chemical bonds are formed and broken with this model.
Press run, then try heating and cooling the atoms to see how temperature affects
the balance between bond formation and breaking.

interactives.title: Concentration and Reaction Rate
interactives.subtitle: How does concentration affect reaction rate?
about: In this model, two atoms can form a bond to make a molecule.
Experiment with changing the concentration of the atoms in order to see
how this affects the reaction rate (the speed at which the reaction occurs).
Follow these steps:
1. Add some atoms. (You can add atoms by pressing the buttons multiple times).
2. Run the model.
3. Reset the model and try a different concentration.
Gauge the reaction rate by using the graph to see when the reaction reaches 80% completion.

interactives.title: Temperature and Reaction Rate
interactives.subtitle: How does temperature affect reaction rate?
about: Explore the role of temperature on reaction rate. Note: In this model any
heat generated by the reaction itself is removed, keeping the temperature
constant in order to isolate the effect of environmental temperature on the rate of reaction.
Follow these steps:
1. Use the temperature slider to set the target temperature.
2. Run the model.
3. Reset the model and try a different temperature.
Gauge the reaction speed by using the graph to see when the reaction is relatively stable at approximately 80% completion.

interactives.title: Stoichiometry and Balancing Equations
interactives.subtitle: Getting the ratios right.
about: When writing a chemical reaction you must satisfy these two laws of chemistry:
1. **The law of conservation of mass**: The mass of the reactants must equal the mass of the products.
2. **The law of definite proportions**: When making a certain chemical there is only one correct ratio of reactants.
To make hydrogen chloride or any other chemical there is only one ratio of reactants that works
so that all of the hydrogen and chlorine are used to make hydrogen chloride. Try several different ratios
to see which ones form a complete reaction with nothing left over. What is the simplest ratio of hydrogen
to chlorine for forming hydrogen chloride?

interactives.title: Catalysis
about: Below is a model containing reactants which will form the reaction:
In this case the model has been set so the activation energy is high. Try running the
reaction with and without a catalyst to see the effect catalysts have on chemical reactions.
##Experimenting with the model##
1. Run the model to observe what happens without a catalyst.
2. Pause the model.
3. Add a few (3 - 4) catalyst atoms to the container by clicking the button.
4. Run the model again, and observe how the catalyst affects the reaction.

interactives.title: Polymers and Monomers
about: Carbohydrates, proteins, and nucleic acids are built from small molecular units that are
connected to each other by strong covalent bonds. The small molecular units are called
monomers (*mono* means one, or single), and they are linked together into long chains
called polymers (*poly* means many, or multiple). Each different type of macromolecule,
except lipids, is built from a different set of monomers that resemble each other in
composition and size. Lipids are not polymers, because they are not built from monomers
(units with similar composition).
Use the model below to build two different kinds of polymers. Your challenge is to create
a chain of identical units (a homopolymer) and a chain of different units (a heteropolymer).
###Challenge 1: Build a homopolymer###
- Select one of the monomer types and add about 15 monomers by clicking anywhere
in the *Polymerization reaction chamber*.
- Click play button to start the reaction.
###Challenge 2: Build a heteropolymer###
- Reset and then add about 5 of each monomer anywhere in the reaction chamber.
- Click play button to start the reaction.

interactives.title: Diffusion of a Drop
interactives.subtitle: Add a drop of dye anywhere in the container, and watch it diffuse through the water.
about: Click in the model to add a drop of dye.  Watch how the molecules move through the water.
Trace an individual molecule to see how it moves through the liquid.

interactives.title: Basic Diffusion
interactives.subtitle: Watch a drop of dye spreading out in water.
about: Add a drop of dye to the model.  Watch how the molecules move through the water.
Trace a random individual molecule to see how it moves through the liquid.

interactives.title: Diffusion & Temperature
interactives.subtitle: How does temperature affect the rate of diffusion?
interactives.about: Explore the role of temperature on the rate of diffusion. Set the temperature, then remove the barrier, and measure the amount of time it takes the blue molecules to reach the gas sensor. When the gas sensor has detected three blue molecules, it will stop the experiment. Compare the diffusion rates at low, medium and high temperatures. Trace an individual molecule to see the path it takes.

interactives.title: Diffusion & Molecular Mass
interactives.subtitle: How does molecular mass affect the rate of diffusion?
interactives.about: Explore the role of molecular mass on the rate of diffusion. Select the mass of the molecules behind the barrier. Remove the barrier, and measure the amount of time it takes the molecules to reach the gas sensor. When the gas sensor has detected three molecules, it will stop the experiment. Compare the diffusion rates of the lightest, heavier and heaviest molecules. Trace an individual molecule to see the path it takes.

interactives.title: Diffusion Across Semipermeable Membranes
interactives.subtitle: How does pore size affect the diffusion of different molecules?
interactives.about: Biological membranes are selectively permeable; some molecules can cross while others cannot. One way to affect this is through pore size. Change the pore size with the slider to change the permeability of the membranes to the different types of molecules. Trace an individual molecule to see the path it takes.

interactives.title: Diffusion Across a Semipermeable Membrane
interactives.subtitle: How does pore size affect the diffusion of different molecules?
interactives.about: Biological membranes are selectively permeable; some molecules can cross while others cannot. One way to affect this is through pore size. Change the pore size with the slider to change the permeability of the membrane to the different types of molecules. Trace an individual molecule to see the path it takes.

interactives.title: Diffusion Across a Permeable Membrane
interactives.subtitle: Exchanging gases across a cell membrane
about: Cell membranes are composed of two layers of phospholipids (a phospholipid bilayer). Some molecules are capable of crossing this membrane directly, without use of specific membrane channels.

Oxygen and carbon dioxide are two molecules that can freely cross the cell membrane. In aerobic cells, oxygen is necessary for cell functioning and carbon dioxide is produced as a waste molecule. Hence, the cell wants oxygen to enter and carbon dioxide to leave. But molecules dont move only in one directionthey diffuse randomly across the membrane.
Set up the model with high oxygen and low carbon dioxide outside the cell and low oxygen and high carbon dioxide inside the cell. In which direction do the oxygen and carbon dioxide molecules move?

interactives.title: Aquapores and semi-permeable membranes
interactives.subtitle: Exchanging particular molecules across a cell membrane

interactives.title: Diffusion - Build your own model
interactives.subtitle: Explore how size and number of particles affect diffusion among gases.
interactives.about: Modify the model by adding and arranging molecules in order to explore how diffusion works.

interactives.title: Diffusion Sandbox
interactives.subtitle: Explore how size and number of particles affect diffusion among gases.
interactives.about: Modify the model by adding and arranging molecules in order to explore how diffusion works.

interactives.title: What is Pressure?
interactives.subtitle: Explore how gas exerts pressure on the sides of a container.
about: Gases have no definite shape or volume. When they are constrained to a container,
we can measure the pressure they exert on the container walls.
The model shows the inside (yellow atoms) and outside (green atoms) of a balloon.
The teal barrier represents the wall of the balloon.
Add atoms to the balloon. Watch what happens.

interactives.title: The Volume-Pressure Relationship
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the volume of a gas affects pressure.
about: Gases can be compressed into smaller volumes. How does compressing a gas affect its pressure?
Run the model, then change the volume of the containers and observe the change in pressure.
The moving wall converts the effect of molecular collisions into pressure and acts as a pressure gauge.
What happens to the pressure when the volume changes?
*Note: Although the atoms in this model are in a flat plane, volume is calculated using 0.1 nm as the depth of the container.*

interactives.title: The Temperature-Volume Relationship
interactives.subtitle: Investigate the relationship between temperature and the volume of a gas.
about: This model contains gas molecules on the left side and a barrier that moves when the
volume of gas expands or contracts, keeping the pressure constant. Run the model and
change the temperature. Why does the barrier move when the temperature changes?
*Note: Although the atoms in this model are in a flat plane, volume is calculated using 0.1 nm as the depth of the container.*

interactives.title: The Temperature-Pressure Relationship
interactives.subtitle: Consider how temperature affects the pressure exerted by a gas.
interactives.about: Run the model and change the temperature. What happens to the pressure when the temperature changes?

interactives.title: The Number-Volume Relationship
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the volume of a gas is related to the number of gas molecules.
about: The model contains gas molecules under constant pressure. The barrier moves when the
volume of gas expands or contracts. Run the model and select different numbers of
molecules from the drop-down menu. What is the relationship between the number of
molecules and the volume of a gas?
*Note: Although the atoms in this model are in a flat plane, volume is calculated using 0.1 nm as the depth of the container.*

interactives.title: Pressure Equilibrium
interactives.subtitle: Explore how heat and number of molecules affect pressure equilibrium between two gases.
about: There are gases on both sides of a moveable barrier (piston), which stays in the same place
(more or less) when you run the model because the gas pressure on the piston is in equilibrium.
Add purple gas molecules and watch what happens to the piston. Reset the model. Now add
yellow gas molecules. What happens to the piston?
Try heating or cooling the gas molecules. Explain the change in equilibrium with each
change. Which has a greater effect on equilibrium -- changing the number of gas molecules
or changing the temperature? Why?

interactives.title: Collapsing Soda Can
interactives.subtitle: Explore how heat and number of molecules affect pressure equilibrium between two gases.
about: The model is an incomplete model of a soda can.
Currently it is showing gas molecules inside and outside the soda can before it is plunged in ice water.
The rectangle in the middle of the model represents a micro-section of the soda can wall.
Design a model that shows what happens after the can is placed in ice water.
Use the tools on the sides of the model to more accurately represent the experiment.
Use tools to heat and cool the molecules where it is appropriate.

interactives.title: Seeing Intermolecular Attractions
interactives.subtitle: A very simple interactive with polar molecules on the left and non-polar molecules on the right.
about: All matter is attracted to all other matter. How does this work?
This interactive shows polar molecules (with charges) and non-polar molecules in a
container with each other. Drag molecules around to see how they are attracted to
each other. Dotted lines indicate intermolecular attractions.

interactives.title: Comparing Dipole-Dipole to London Dispersion
interactives.subtitle: Explore the difference in attractive forces between polar and nonpolar molecules.
about: Explore the different strengths of dipole-dipole (polar) and London dispersion (nonpolar)
attractions. These intermolecular attractions are shown by dotted lines between the pairs of molecules.
Choose a pair of molecules from the drop-down menu and "pull" on the star to separate the
molecules. Which type of intermolecular attraction is strongest?

interactives.title: Oil and Water
interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar and non-polar substances interact.
about: It is well known that "oil and water dont mix." But why? Run the model
of polar water (blue and red) and non-polar oil (gray). "Shake up the oil and water mixture,"
then run it again and watch what happens to the molecules over time.

interactives.title: Boiling Point
interactives.subtitle: Explore what boiling looks like at the molecular level with both polar and non-polar substances.
about: Non-polar molecules (gray) evaporate or boil more quickly than polar molecules (blue and red).
Attractions between molecules are shown with dotted lines. Run the model, then heat the liquids.
What does boiling look like at the molecular level?

interactives.title: Polarity and Attractive Strength
interactives.subtitle: Explore the different attractive forces between molecules of varying polarity.
about: Attractions between polar molecules vary. Choose a pair of molecules from the drop-down
menu and "pull" on the star to separate the molecules. Why does polarity have an effect
on the strength of attraction between molecules?

interactives.title: Factors Affecting London Dispersion Attractions
interactives.subtitle: Explore how differences in molecular size and shape affect the strength of London dispersion attractions.
about: Some non-polar molecules have stronger attractions than others. Choose a pair of
molecules from the drop-down menu and "pull" on the star to separate the molecules.
Why do size and shape affect the strength of attraction between two non-polar molecules?

interactives.title: Hydrogen Bonds: A Special Type of Attraction
interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar molecules interact via hydrogen bonds.
about: Explore hydrogen bonds forming between polar molecules, such as water. Hydrogen bonds are shown with dotted lines.
Show partial charges and run the model. Where do hydrogen bonds form? Try changing the temperature
of the model. How does the pattern of hydrogen bonding explain the lattice that makes up ice crystals?

interactives.title: States of Matter
interactives.subtitle: Explore Coulomb and Intermolecular Attractions
about: What kinds of patterns tend to form? How does changing the Van der Waals
attraction affect the melting and boiling point of the substance?

interactives.title: Your Immune System
interactives.subtitle: Desgin your own antibody
about: Shape and chage affect how well and antibody will attract to an antigen.
Explore various shapes and ways to charge parts of the antibodies to see how strongly you can get them to stick together.

interactives.title: Excited Electrons
interactives.subtitle: Investigate how an electron becomes excited.
about: An atom's electrons have energy, but they are restricted to very specific energy levels. If an electron has the lowest possible energy
it is considered to be in the **ground state**. An electron is called **excited** if it has higher energy than the ground state. In this
model an excited electron is shown by a yellow halo around the atom.
**How does an electron become excited?** Try colliding the atoms together at different velocities. Do electrons always get excited? Where
does the energy come from when electrons go from the ground state to an excited state?

interactives.title: Different Excited States for Different Elements
interactives.subtitle: Exploring different excited states.
about: An electron is called **excited** if it has higher energy than the ground state - its lowest energy state. In this
model an excited electron is shown by a yellow halo around the atom.
Change the speed (thus the kinetic energy) of the blue atoms (A and B) and determine the minimum energy
needed to excite the green atom (C) and the yellow atom (D).
Hints:
-  Focus on one atom at a time by setting the speed of the other one to zero.
-  Press the Reset button before changing the speed.
Is the minimum energy needed to excite atoms C and D the same? Why?

how the molecules in a liquid move relative to each other. How does the movement

interactives.title: Molecular View of a Solid
interactives.subtitle: What does a solid look like at the molecular level?
about: Molecules are in constant motioneven those in a solid! "Mark two atoms," then
run the model to see how the molecules in a solid move relative to each other. How
would you describe the movement and arrangement of molecules in a solid?

interactives.title: Intermolecular Attractions and States of Matter
interactives.subtitle: Explore how states of matter are related to the strength of intermolecular attractions.
about: There are three states of mattersolid, liquid and gas. Run the model and change the
strength of attractions between the molecules. How does changing the force of attraction
between molecules affect the state of that material?

interactives.title: Phase Changes with two bar graphs
interactives.subtitle: Explore how energy input causes matter to change states.
about: Matter exists as solids, liquids and gases, and can change state between these.
The model shows a liquid material on the left (small atoms). The amount of heat
energy is shown by kinetic energy (KE) shading, with deeper shades of red
representing more energetic atoms. On the right side of the barrier is a solid
material (large atoms).
Run the model. How much energy is able to penetrate the barrier? Remove the barrier.
How quickly do the more energetic atoms melt the solid?

interactives.title: Phase Change
interactives.subtitle: Explore how energy input causes matter to change states.
about: Matter exists as solids, liquids and gases, and can change state between these.
The model shows a liquid material on the left (small atoms). The amount of heat
energy is shown by kinetic energy (KE) shading, with deeper shades of red
representing more energetic atoms. On the right side of the barrier is a solid
material (large atoms).
Run the model. How much energy is able to penetrate the barrier? Remove the barrier.
How quickly do the more energetic atoms melt the solid?

interactives.title: States of Matter
interactives.subtitle: Temperature and Density of Materials
about: What kinds of patterns tend to form? How does changing the temperature
affect the packing density of the atoms?

interactives.title: Oil and Water
interactives.subtitle: Explore how polar and non-polar substances interact.
about: It is well known that "oil and water dont mix." But why? Run the model of
polar water (blue and red) and non-polar oil (gray). "Shake up the oil and water
mixture," then run it again and watch what happens to the molecules over time.

interactives.title: Charged and Neutral Atoms
interactives.subtitle: Explore Coulomb and intermolecular attractions.
about: There are two kinds of attractive forces shown in this model: Coulomb forces (the attraction between ions)
and Van der Waals forces (an additional attractive force between all atoms).
What kinds of patterns tend to form with charged and neutral atoms? How does changing the Van der Waals
attraction or charging the atoms affect the melting and boiling point of the substance?

interactives.title: Charged and Neutral Atoms (conceptual version)
interactives.subtitle: Explore Coulomb and intermolecular attractions.
about: There are two kinds of attractive forces shown in this model: Coulomb forces (the attraction between ions)
and Van der Waals forces (an additional attractive force between all atoms).
What kinds of patterns tend to form with charged and neutral atoms? How does changing the Van der Waals
attraction or charging the atoms affect the melting and boiling point of the substance?

interactives.title: Protein Folding
interactives.subtitle: How do peptides fold into stable conformations?
about: Explore the role of hydrophobic and hydrophilic interactions in protein folding. Generate a random peptide string and watch how it folds in an aqueous environment. Change the solvent to see what happens if the peptide is in an oily environment or a vacuum instead of an aqueous environment.

interactives.title: Land of Bump - Particles with Temperature Setting
interactives.subtitle: How do particles move at different temperatures?
about:
You are looking into the particles that make up everything in the world. These particles are always in motion.

Look carefully to see how they move. Change temperatures by clicking the Cold, Medium, and Hot buttons, and describe how the motion of the particles changes.

Check "Mark a Particle" to highlight a particle to make it easier to follow.

interactives.title: Land of Bump - Red Hots, Cool Blues with Removable Solid Barrier
interactives.subtitle: Mixing hot and cold
about:
Click "Start" and observe the molecules moving.
Before removing the barrier, here are a few questions to consider:

How do the red molecules move? How do the blues ones move?
What do you notice about the speed of the red and blue molecules and their temperatures?
Are all the reds molecules moving at the same speed? What about the blue molecules?
Do individual reds molecules change speed? If so, how does that happen? What about the blue molecules?

Now click "Remove the barrier" and watch what happens. What changes do you observe?

interactives.title: Molecular View of a Gas with Slow Motion
interactives.subtitle: Explore how molecules in a gas move relative to each other.
about: Molecules are in constant motion. "Mark two atoms," then run the model to see
how the molecules move relative to each other. How do the distances between gas
molecules change over time?

interactives.title: Molecular View of a Liquid with Slow Motion
interactives.subtitle: Explore how molecules in a liquid move.
about: Molecules are in constant motion. "Mark two atoms," then run the model to see
how the molecules in a liquid move relative to each other. How does the movement
of molecules explain why liquids take the shape of their containers?

interactives.title: Introduction to temperature and molecular movement using the Seasons
interactives.subtitle: Molecular movement of a gas in the four seasons
about: Molecules are always moving, but they move at different speeds depending on their temperature.
Click on the different seasons icons to see how molecules of a gas--air--for instance, move at different temperatures.
Click on "Mark and trace a molecule" to see the path of a molecule at different temperatures.
Here are a few questions to consider:
For any one seasons, do all molecules move at the same speed?
What makes molecules change speed?
At what season and temperature do you see the longest straight traces path?

would you describe the movement and arrangement of molecules in a solid?

interactives.title: Absoprtion spectra
interactives.subtitle: Explore how light interacts with mixtures of elements
about: Explore how absorption spectra are created.
Each element absorbs specific wavelengths. By shining light onto a mixture,
and measuring the wavelengths coming out, scientists can determine
which elements are in the mixture.
Shine light on the mixture. Allow the model to run until all types of wavelengths have had a chance
to interact with the mixture.

interactives.title: Light absorption / emission
interactives.subtitle: Absorption & Emission of Photons
about: Discover what happens when a particular frequency of light is absorbed by an atom.
Press the **Play** button.
Change the **Energy of monochromatic light source** slider to see photons at different energy levels.
To make sure you see all the wavelengths [or photons], select the slider and use the arrow keys to
step through each wavelength.
Wait for at least three series of a photon before moving to a different wavelength.
The atoms will either absorb or let pass photons of each frequency.
Which frequency of light is absorbed and re-emitted by these atoms?
How does the model represent this?

interactives.title: Parade of photons
interactives.subtitle: Comparing Energy and Wavelengths
about: Compare the wavelengths on the electromagnetic spectrum.
Press the **Play** button.
Change the **Energy of monochromatic light source** slider to see photons at different energy levels.
To make sure you see all the wavelengths [or photons], select the slider and use the arrow keys to
step through each wavelength.
What is the relationship between photon energy and wavelength?

interactives.title: Snowflake
interactives.about: Click the play button, then heat the snowflake. Watch what happens at the molecular scale. What happens when you cool it again?

interactives.title: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat
interactives.subtitle: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat in a Melting Experiment
about: Specific heat capacity is the measure of the heat energy required
to raise the temperature of a given quantity of a substance by one
kelvin. Latent heat of melting describes the amount of heat
required to melt a solid. When a solid is undergoing melting, the
temperature basically remains constant until the entire solid is
molten. The above simulation demonstrates the specific heat and
the latent heat.
The physical origin of latent heat is that when a system is in a
phase transition, its structure will change. Changing structure
usually results in changes of potential energy, because potential
energy depends primarily on structure. In the simulation,
the energy added to the system is absorbed by the atoms and used
to break the interatomic interactions (so that they can leave the
condensed state). During the phase transition the kinetic energy
doesn't increase, as the
potential energy increases in the expense of the input energy.
During this period, the interatomic interactions diminish and the
structure breaks up, resulting in a phase transition.
One thing you would notice is that the temperature-energy curve on
the right has fluctuations. This is because we have much fewer
atoms (169) in the simulation than there would be in a real
physical model.

interactives.subtitle: Seeing Specific Heat and Latent Heat in a Condensation Experiment

interactives.title: Hydrogen Combustion
interactives.subtitle: Hydrogen and oxygen can burn to form water
about: This model shows how hydrogen and oxygen burn to form water.
The equation for this reaction is:
2H2 + O2  2H2O
**Instructions**
1. Run the model.
2. Click **Spark** to initiate the reaction.

interactives.title: Ceramic Forces
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the molecular structure of ceramic affects its mechanical properties.
about: This model shows a ceramic (such as pottery or brick), an ionic lattice. In this
model you can use a downward force to bend a small ceramic beam. Use different
amounts of force to bend the beam. What happens to the beam when you use a small
force or a large force? What happens when you release the force?
Compare the structure and behavior of this beam to the metal beam. How do their
behaviors differ and why?

interactives.title: Metal Forces
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the molecular structure of metal affects its mechanical properties.
about: This model shows a metal lattice, such as aluminum or iron. In this model you can use a
downward force to bend a small metal beam. Use different amounts of force to bend the
beam. What happens to the beam when you use a small force or a large force? What happens
when you release the force?
Compare the structure and behavior of this beam to the ceramic beam. How do their
behaviors differ and why?

interactives.title: Plastic Forces
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the molecular structure of plastic affects its mechanical properties.
about: Plastics are polymers, composed of many long molecular chains. In this model you can use a
downward force to bend a small beam of plastic. Use different amounts of force to bend the
beam. What happens to the beam when you use a small force or a large force? What happens
when you release the force?
Compare the structure and behavior of this beam of plastic to the beam of tire rubber.
How do their behaviors differ and why?

interactives.title: Tire Forces
interactives.subtitle: Explore how the molecular structure of tire rubber affects its mechanical properties.
about: Tire rubber is a polymer, composed of many long molecular chains. In this model you can
use a downward force to bend a small beam of tire rubber. Use different amounts of force
to bend the beam. What happens to the beam when you use a small force or a large force?
What happens when you release the force?
Compare the structure and behavior of this beam of tire rubber to the beam of plastic.
How do their behaviors differ and why?

interactives.title: Water 1
interactives.subtitle: Simple Water Model
about: Explore how water moves through rocks and sediments.
Use the **Follow water droplet** button to watch where water goes after it falls.

interactives.title: Water 2
interactives.subtitle: Draw Your Own Layers
about: Draw your own rock/sediment layers to explore how water moves through rocks and sediments.
Select a sediment type from the **Add Layers** menu, and drag the cursor within the model to draw a layer.
Add as many layers as you want.
When you are done, press the **play** button to start the model and watch where water flows.
You can use the **Follow water droplet** button
to follow a single water droplet as it moves through the layers.

interactives.title: Water 3
interactives.subtitle: Comparing Permeabilities of Different Sediments/Rocks
about: Compare the behavior of water as it hits sediments/rocks of differing permeability.

interactives.title: Water 4
interactives.subtitle: Confined and Unconfined Aquifers
about: Explore the difference between confined and unconfined aquifers.
Click the **Add well** button, and then move your cursor to where you want to drill a well.
Place your cursor at the land surface, and click to start drilling.
Click and hold until the well reaches the proper depth.
1) Drill one well into the unconfined aquifer (the upper aquifer, which is overlain by high permeability rocks/sediments).
Adjust the **Rain probability** slider so that the water level in the unconfined aquifer remains steady.
Pause the model.
2) Then place one well into the confined aquifer (the lower aquifer, which is overlain by low permeability rocks/sediments).
Press the **Play** button to start the model, and compare the wells' outputs.
The graph shows the water outputs of the different wells. You can drill up to five wells.

interactives.title: Water 5
interactives.subtitle: Permeability and Aquifers
about: Discover which sediments make the best aquifers.
1) Click the **Add water** button, and then move your cursor in the model to paint water into the model.
Press the **Play** button to distribute the water evenly.
2) Pause the model, and add wells to the model.
Click the **Add well** button, and then move your cursor to where you want to drill a well.
Place your cursor at the land surface, and click to start drilling.
Click and hold until the well reaches the proper depth.
Drill at least three wells into different types of sediments.
When you are done drilling wells, press the **Play** button to start the model.
The graph shows the water outputs of the different wells. You can drill up to five wells.

interactives.title: Water 6
interactives.subtitle: Water Flow in Rural and Urban Areas
about: Explore how water flow differs in rural and urban areas.
Click the **Add well** button to select a flowback or non-flowback well.
The flowback well will release water directly above the well. The non-flowback well will not release water within the model.
Move your cursor to where you want to drill a well.
Place your cursor at the land surface, and click to start drilling.
Click and hold until the well reaches the proper depth.
The graph shows the water outputs of the different wells. You can drill up to five wells.

interactives.title: Water 7
interactives.subtitle: Gaining and Losing Streams
about: Explore how the water table changes near gaining and losing streams.
Choose **Stream A** or **Stream B**. Press the **Play** button to start the model.
Run the model for at least 6 years.
The graph shows the water level in the stream. Compare the water level between Stream A and Stream B.

interactives.title: Water 8
interactives.subtitle: Well Placement Around a Gaining Stream
about: Explore the best place to put wells around a gaining stream to maintain the water level
in the stream.
Click the **Add well** button, and then move your cursor to where you want to drill a well.
Place your cursor at the land surface, and click to start drilling.
Click and hold until the well reaches the proper depth.
Run two experiments:
(1) Place wells near the stream.
(2) Place wells far from the stream.
The upper graph (**Water Level**) shows the water level in the stream.
The lower graph (**Well Output**) shows the the water output of the different wells.
Although you can add up to five wells, you should add only two wells in each experiment.

interactives.title: Water (master)
interactives.subtitle: Master Model
about: Choose a model from the **Template** menu or draw your own model.
Select the **Add layers** button, and click and drag in the model to draw layers.
Add wells to the model by selecting a well type from the **Add well** button.
Move your cursor to where you want to drill a well.
Place your cursor at the land surface, and click to start drilling.
Click and hold until the well reaches the proper depth.
The **Water Level** graph shows
the water level in the stream in the *Gaining Stream* and *Losing Stream* models.
The **Well Output** graph shows the water output of different wells.
